TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit AudioEffect extends Java.Lang.Object

Docs.summary: AudioEffect is the base class for controlling audio effects provided by the android audio framework.

remarks.para: AudioEffect is the base class for controlling audio effects provided by the android audio framework.
Applications should not use the AudioEffect class directly but one of its derived classes to control specific effects:

To apply the audio effect to a specific AudioTrack or MediaPlayer instance, the application must specify the audio session ID of that instance when creating the AudioEffect. (see for details on audio sessions).
NOTE: attaching insert effects (equalizer, bass boost, virtualizer) to the global audio output mix by use of session 0 is deprecated.

Creating an AudioEffect object will create the corresponding effect engine in the audio framework if no instance of the same effect type exists in the specified audio session. If one exists, this instance will be used.

The application creating the AudioEffect object (or a derived class) will either receive control of the effect engine or not depending on the priority parameter. If priority is higher than the priority used by the current effect engine owner, the control will be transfered to the new object. Otherwise control will remain with the previous object. In this case, the new application will be notified of changes in effect engine state or control ownership by the appropiate listener.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(native int javaReference, valuetype Android.Runtime.JniHandleOwnership transfer) cil managed

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a Java Native Interface object.
The constructor will initializes the property of the new instance using and .

Docs.summary: Intent to signal to the effect control application or service that an audio session is closed and that effects should not be applied anymore.

remarks.para: Intent to signal to the effect control application or service that an audio session is closed and that effects should not be applied anymore.
The effect control application receiving this intent will delete all effects on this session and store current settings in package specific storage.
The calling package name is indicated by the extra and the audio session ID by the extra. Both extras are mandatory.
It is good practice for applications to broadcast this intent when music playback stops and/or when exiting to free system resources consumed by audio effect engines.

Docs.summary: Intent to launch an audio effect control panel UI.

remarks.para: Intent to launch an audio effect control panel UI.

The goal of this intent is to enable separate implementations of music/media player applications and audio effect control application or services. This will allow platform vendors to offer more advanced control options for standard effects or control for platform specific effects.
The intent carries a number of extras used by the player application to communicate necessary pieces of information to the control panel application.

The calling application must use the method to launch the control panel so that its package name is indicated and used by the control panel application to keep track of changes for this particular application.
The extra will indicate an audio session to which the audio effects should be applied. If no audio session is specified, either one of the follownig will happen:
- If an audio session was previously opened by the calling application with intent, the effect changes will be applied to that session.
- If no audio session is opened, the changes will be stored in the package specific storage area and applied whenever a new audio session is opened by this application.
The extra will help the control panel application customize both the UI layout and the default audio effect settings if none are already stored for the calling application.

Docs.summary: Intent to signal to the effect control application or service that a new audio session is opened and requires audio effects to be applied.

remarks.para: Intent to signal to the effect control application or service that a new audio session is opened and requires audio effects to be applied.

This is different from in that no UI should be displayed in this case. Music player applications can broadcast this intent before starting playback to make sure that any audio effect settings previously selected by the user are applied.

The effect control application receiving this intent will look for previously stored settings for the calling application, create all required audio effects and apply the effect settings to the specified audio session.
The calling package name is indicated by the extra and the audio session ID by the extra. Both extras are mandatory.
If no stored settings are found for the calling application, default settings for the content type indicated by will be applied. The default settings for a given content type are platform specific.

Docs.summary: To be added.
Effect connection mode is auxiliary.

remarks.para: Effect connection mode is auxiliary.

Auxiliary effects must be created on session 0 (global output mix). In order for a MediaPlayer or AudioTrack to be fed into this effect, they must be explicitely attached to this effect and a send level must be specified.
Use the effect ID returned by to designate this particular effect when attaching it to the MediaPlayer or AudioTrack.

Docs.summary: Effect connection mode is insert.

remarks.para: Effect connection mode is insert. Specifying an audio session ID when creating the effect will insert this effect after all players in the same audio session.

Docs.summary: Contains the ID of the audio session the effects should be applied to.

remarks.para: Contains the ID of the audio session the effects should be applied to.
This extra is for use with , and intents.
The extra value is of type int and is the audio session ID.

Docs.summary: Indicates which type of content is played by the application.

remarks.para: Indicates which type of content is played by the application.
This extra is for use with and intents.

This information is used by the effect control application to customize UI and select appropriate default effect settings. The content type is one of the following:
If omitted, the content type defaults to .

Docs.summary: Contains the package name of the calling application.

remarks.para: Contains the package name of the calling application.
This extra is for use with and intents.
The extra value is a string containing the full package name.

Docs.summary: Releases the native AudioEffect resources.

remarks.para: Releases the native AudioEffect resources. It is a good practice to release the effect engine when not in use as control can be returned to other applications or the native resources released.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance valuetype Android.Media.Audiofx.AudioEffectStatus SetEnabled(bool enabled) cil managed

Docs.summary: Enable or disable the effect.

remarks.para: Enable or disable the effect. Creating an audio effect does not automatically apply this effect on the audio source. It creates the resources necessary to process this effect but the audio signal is still bypassed through the effect engine. Calling this method will make that the effect is actually applied or not to the audio content being played in the corresponding audio session.

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which contains the java.lang.Class JNI value corresponding to this type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control which jclass is provided to methods like .

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which provides the declaring type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control virtual vs. non virtual method dispatch against the underlying JNI object. When this property is equal to the declaring type, then virtual method invocation against the JNI object is performed; otherwise, we assume that the method was overridden by a derived type, and perform non-virtual methdo invocation.
